awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Assessment to Enhance Teaching and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Although many in education advocate for evidence-based teaching, implementation of such practices is often quite difficult for teachers. Assessment and accountability data are commonly used for system-level reforms, but are seldom designed to help teachers guide day-to-day instructional decision-making. More useful assessment systems should deliver actionable information to assist in guiding instructional decisions, communicate the development of student knowledge, and integrate various forms of data to assist teachers. Such systems must be logistically feasible to implement, provide suitable grounds for interpreting  information about achievement, and exist in a teacher community interested in ongoing feedback about student learning.

This project will modify an existing assessment system (BEAR Assessment System) to provide ongoing, instructionally productive evidence to teachers about student learning and to link student work products and formative assessments with summative assessments in models that generate useful estimates of student growth. To design and test the assessment system, researchers will study teacher integration of assessment tools with instruction via classroom observations, video records, and interviews. Feedback from teachers and observations of their assessment practices will inform revisions to the assessment system. Multiple iterations will focus on how best to represent and display assessment results for tracking individual and group learning. Researchers will investigate new psychometric models that link information from student classroom work, responses to formative assessments, and summative evaluations to provide more reliable estimates of student learning.

The Discovery Research PreK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Modeling Assessment to Enhance Teaching and Learning

            It is broadly accepted that successful assessment is one of the best ways to improve educational outcomes; and the focus of this improvement is finding actionable information for improving classroom instruction.  In this project, we have developed a framework for designing assessments that is keyed to the scope of the educational interpretations. This framework articulates three levels of interpretations of assessment information:

 -at the micro level, teachers observe student responses to varied tasks, and make in-stream instructional interpretations of those responses; 

-at the meso level, teachers are seeking to confirm/explore their interpretations by dipping into the instructional stream at (usually) pre-planned times; and

-at the macro level (often referred to as ?summative testing?) teachers and administrators use standardized tests to record student progress on composite achievement outcomes.  

Assessments operate at and between these three levels: (i) classroom-dependent observations that are delivered on-the-fly by teachers in classrooms and that function at the micro level, (ii) externally developed tasks that are delivered by teachers within the classroom setting according to the needs of formative assessment, which function at the meso level, and (iii) standardized tests that function at the macro level. The first is designed to track closely the variation of student performance over time in a classroom instructional context, the second is designed to provide a basis for triangulating student responses in classroom and school contexts, and the third is designed for coarser evaluation tasks, such as end-of-semester grading, grade promotion, and program evaluation. 

            This framing has been exemplified within the project in K-5 elementary schools that are seeking to improve the quality of instruction and students? understandings of elementary school geometry and the lead-up to rational number. The different levels of assessments and response interpretation are instantiated with two different pieces of software, which operate at the micro level (Teacher Observation Tools (TOTS)?see screenshot in Figure 1) and the meso/macro levels (Berkeley Assessment System Software (BASS)?see example item in Figure 2), respectively. The TOTS software supports teacher observation and the recording of those judgements.  The BASS software delivers externally developed tasks and item online, auto-scores most items, and provides reports on student progress. 

Moreover, the educational coordination across the two levels is achieved using construct maps, which articulate student cognitive growth at crucial waypoints in student development that are appropriate for teacher planning and within-classroom use?see the example of the construct map for the construct ?Theory of Measurement-Length (ToML) shown in Figure 3. Looking for example, at the second waypoint, ?ToML 2,? students at this waypoint focus on the nature of a unit.  Here, they must learn (through extensive practice) that:

(a) units enable indirect measurements via accumulation and count (instead of directly comparing), and 

(b) units allow for both additive (how much longer?) and multiplicative comparisons (how many times longer?). 

Students must develop understandings of the properties that enable these uses. Hence, students at this level need to be able to explain the roles of identical units and tiling. The right-hand side of Figure 2 gives a detailed account of aspects of student understanding that are involved at this second ToML waypoint.

These construct maps operate within both pieces of software, enabling interpretations that span across the micro and the meso levels:

-Each item in the BASS item bank is coordinated to one or more of the points in the construct map?for example the item in Figure 2 is linked to the second level of ToML; 

-Each time a teacher makes an observation recorded in TOTS, it is coordinated with a waypoint in one of the construct maps.

These construct maps are crucial for the flexible and effective teacher use of assessment results from the micro and meso levels. 

The materials developed include; (a) four construct maps for the elementary school geometry topics of length, area, volume and angle; (b) 165 BASS items that spread across these constructs; (c) extensive training materials including exemplary student responses to the items and a scoring guide for each; (d) adapted and extended software for in-classroom use (TOTS and BASS); and (e) a calibration of the BASS items along with teacher judgements of student on-the-fly assessment opportunities. This last is illustrated in Figure 4?notes about interpretation of this graph, called a ?Wright map,? are shown in the figure.

 

This project has developed the first simultaneous deployment of assessments at these two levels (micro and meso), coordinated by the construct maps which operate at both levels.  The successful achievement of this is a significant accomplishment for educational measurement.
